title: Teaching team
text:
Dr.¬†Mine √áetinkaya-Rundel (she/her) is Professor of the Practice and Director of Undergraduate Studies at the Department of Statistical Science at Duke University and an affiliated faculty in the Computational Media, Arts, and Cultures. Mine‚Äôs work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM.



Office hours
Location




Tuesdays 2:30 - 3:30 pm
Old Chem 213 (or Zoom upon request)

title: FDA
text:
Contains the inputs that will be used in different sub-panels. The following inputs will be used in sub-panels Basis Functions (to generate the basis functions), FDA and FPCA (run and report the FPCA algorithm):

Degree of B-spline Basis:

Deg. of freedom of B-spline Basis:

Two Dimension:
# of Common bivatiate Basis (# of Clusters for Clustering):
3D Visualition:

Contour Plot in R
Heat Map in R
Perspective in R

Azimuthal Angle
Polar Angle



The first two inputs are mostly to describe the basis functions. The fourth input is to specify the number common basis in FPCA algorithm, and number of clusters to produce the outputs. The fifth input specify the type of plots produced in sub-panels Basis Functions, FDA and FPCA (for 2D cases).

title: FDA
text:
Data
One can either use the files posted in Server

TS-m=xx-n=yyy

or upload a different file to be analyzed.
or simulate functions.

title: FDA
text:
Basis Functions

Using some visualization techniques, we illustrate the B-spline basis that is used in the algorithm.

title: FDA
text:
Data Description (FDA Summary)
The Scree plot is the last output of Data Description (FDA Summary) panel. It can be used as a visualizing tool to obtain the required number of common basis based on the initial estimate (obtained by mapping the observed functions(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Periodogram) to the column space of the basis expansion).

The remaining Data Description choices are used to summarize and visualize the FDA input data:

title: FDA
text:
FPCA

The FPCA algorithm is implemented in this sub-panel
Also the results and graphs is provided here.

title: FDA
text:
Manual
The sub-panel that contains this instruction manual.

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Customizing Scatterplot Matrices

Customizing scatterplot matrices with density plots

```{r}
# Adding density plots to scatterplot matrix
panel.d <- function(x, ...) {
    usr <- par("usr")
    on.exit(par(usr))
    par(usr = c(usr[1:2], 0, .5))
    lines(density(x), col="red")
}
pairs(iris[101:150, 1:4], panel = panel.d, main="Customized Scatterplot Matrix")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to Jackknife-after-Bootstrap

Explanation of the jackknife-after-bootstrap method
Used to estimate bias and standard errors after bootstrap

```{r}
library(boot)
library(bootstrap)
set.seed(1111)

# Function to compute the patch ratio statistic
theta.boot <- function(patch, i) {
  y <- patch[i, "y"]
  z <- patch[i, "z"]
  mean(y) / mean(z)
}

# Bootstrap the patch dataset
boot.out <- boot(bootstrap::patch, statistic = theta.boot, R=2000)
boot.out
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Applying Jackknife-after-Bootstrap

Example: Using the jackknife-after-bootstrap method
Checking the bootstrap array

```{r}
# Check the bootstrap array
A <- boot.array(boot.out)
head(A, 3)

# Proportion of cases that are not resampled
mean(A[, 1] == 0)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Results
```{r}
# Plotting the bootstrap results
plot(boot.out, index=1)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of jackknife-after-bootstrap technique
Importance of combining jackknife and bootstrap for robust estimates
Practice: Apply jackknife-after-bootstrap to other datasets





üîó tinyurl.com/Comp-Stat

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Basic Monte Carlo Estimation

Introduction to Monte Carlo estimation
Example: Estimating the expected difference of two normal variables

```{r}
m <- 1000
g <- numeric(m)
for (i in 1:m) {
    x <- rnorm(2)
    g[i] <- abs(x[1] - x[2])
}
est <- mean(g)
est
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Monte Carlo Simulations
```{r}
# Histogram of the simulated differences
hist(g, main="Histogram of Differences (Monte Carlo)", col="lightblue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Estimating the Mean Squared Error (MSE)

Monte Carlo estimation of MSE for trimmed means

```{r}
n <- 20
m <- 1000
mean_trim <- numeric(m)
for (i in 1:m) {
    x <- rnorm(n)
    mean_trim[i] <- mean(x, trim = 0.1)
}
mse <- mean((mean_trim - 0)^2)
mse
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing MSE Simulations
```{r}
# Histogram of the trimmed means
hist(mean_trim, main="Trimmed Means (Monte Carlo MSE)", col="lightgreen")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Additional Monte Carlo Techniques

Exploring advanced Monte Carlo techniques for inference
Example: Hypothesis testing with Monte Carlo methods

```{r}
# Monte Carlo test example: Hypothesis testing
n <- 50
m <- 1000
test_stat <- numeric(m)
for (i in 1:m) {
    x <- rnorm(n)
    test_stat[i] <- mean(x)
}
p_value <- mean(test_stat >= 1.96)
p_value
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of Monte Carlo methods in inference, MSE estimation, and hypothesis testing
Practice: Apply these methods to other inferential problems





üîó tinyurl.com/Comp-Stat

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Bootstrap Resampling Method

Introduction to the bootstrap method
Example: Bootstrap estimate of standard error

```{r}
# Bootstrap example: Estimate correlation between LSAT and GPA
library(bootstrap)    #for the law data
print(cor(law$LSAT, law$GPA))
print(cor(law82$LSAT, law82$GPA))
# Set up the bootstrap
B <- 200            # number of replicates
n <- nrow(law)      # sample size
R <- numeric(B)     # storage for replicates
# Bootstrap estimate of correlation
for (i in 1:B) {
  idx <- sample(1:n, size=n, replace=TRUE)
  law_boot <- law[idx, ]
  R[i] <- cor(law_boot$LSAT, law_boot$GPA)
}
mean(R)
sd(R)  # Bootstrap standard error
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Bootstrap Resamples
```{r}
# Plotting the bootstrap distribution
hist(R, main="Bootstrap Distribution of Correlation", col="lightblue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to the Jackknife Method

The jackknife method for bias reduction
Example: Jackknife estimate of the mean

```{r}
# Jackknife estimate of mean
n <- nrow(law)
theta_hat <- mean(law$LSAT)
theta_jack <- numeric(n)

# Leave-one-out jackknife
for (i in 1:n) {
  theta_jack[i] <- mean(law$LSAT[-i])
}

# Jackknife estimate of bias
bias_jack <- (n - 1) * (mean(theta_jack) - theta_hat)
bias_jack
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Bootstrap Confidence Intervals

Introduction to bootstrap confidence intervals
Example: Bootstrap percentile confidence interval

```{r}
# Bootstrap confidence intervals
alpha <- 0.05
ci <- quantile(R, probs = c(alpha/2, 1 - alpha/2))
ci  # Bootstrap confidence interval
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Comparison of Bootstrap and Jackknife

Discuss the differences and use cases of bootstrap and jackknife
Recap of methods and their benefits in reducing bias and estimating uncertainty

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Histogram Density Estimates

Introduction to density estimation using histograms
Example: Histogram density estimates using Sturges‚Äô Rule

```{r}
set.seed(12345)
n <- 25
x <- rnorm(n)

# Calculate breaks according to Sturges' Rule
nclass <- ceiling(1 + log2(n))
cwidth <- diff(range(x) / nclass)
breaks <- min(x) + cwidth * 0:nclass

# Default histogram
h.default <- hist(x, freq = FALSE, xlab = "default", main = "Histogram: Default")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Kernel Density Estimation

Introduction to kernel density estimation (KDE)
Example: Applying KDE to data

```{r}
# Kernel density estimate
dens <- density(x)
plot(dens, main = "Kernel Density Estimate", col = "blue", lwd = 2)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Kernel Density
```{r}
# Overlay histogram and KDE
hist(x, freq = FALSE, col = "lightgray", border = "white", main = "Histogram with KDE")
lines(dens, col = "red", lwd = 2)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of histogram density estimation and kernel density estimation
Practice: Apply density estimation techniques to other datasets





üîó tinyurl.com/Comp-Stat

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Benchmarking Methods

Overview of benchmarking in R
Example: Benchmarking methods to generate a sequence

```{r}
s1 <- 1:10
s2 <- seq(1, 10, 1)
s3 <- seq.int(1, 10, 1)

# Benchmarking
library(microbenchmark)
library(ggplot2)

n <- 1000
mb <- microbenchmark(
  seq(1, n, 1),
  1:n,
  times = 100
)
mb
autoplot(mb)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Profiling Code for Performance

Introduction to profiling in R
Example: Profiling a function using profvis

```{r}
# Install profvis for profiling
library(profvis)

# Example: Profile a sorting function
profvis({
  x <- rnorm(1e4)
  y <- sort(x)
})
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Profiling Results
```{r}
# profvis visual interface will show the profiling output
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of benchmarking and profiling in R
Practice: Apply these techniques to optimize code in R





üîó tinyurl.com/Comp-Stat

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to Monte Carlo Integration

Basic concepts of Monte Carlo integration
Example: Integrating using uniform distribution

```{r}
m <- 10000
x <- runif(m)
theta.hat <- mean(exp(-x))
theta.hat
1 - exp(-1)
```

title: Computational Statistics
section: Example: Monte Carlo integration with bounded intervals
text:
Example: Monte Carlo integration with bounded intervals
```{r}
m <- 10000
x <- runif(m, min=2, max=4)
theta.hat <- mean(exp(-x)) * 2
theta.hat
exp(-2) - exp(-4)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Unbounded Intervals

Handling unbounded intervals in Monte Carlo integration

```{r}
# Plotting a function over an unbounded interval
x <- seq(.1, 2.5, length.out = 100)
y <- exp(-x^2 / 2)
plot(x, y, type="l", main="Function Plot for Unbounded Interval", col="blue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to Importance Sampling

Importance sampling and its applications
Example: Applying importance sampling

```{r}
# Example of importance sampling
g <- function(x) exp(-x^2 / 2)
f <- function(x) dnorm(x, mean = 1)
x <- rnorm(10000, mean = 1)
theta.hat <- mean(g(x) / f(x))
theta.hat
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Importance Sampling
```{r}
# Compare the original function with the importance sampling function
curve(g, from = -3, to = 3, col = "blue", lwd = 2, main="Importance Sampling: g(x) vs f(x)")
curve(f, add = TRUE, col = "red", lty = 2, lwd = 2)
legend("topright", legend=c("g(x)", "f(x)"), col=c("blue", "red"), lty=c(1, 2), lwd=2)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Control Variates

Explanation of control variates and how they reduce variance
Example: Using control variates in Monte Carlo integration

```{r}
# Control variates example
m <- 10000
x <- runif(m)
theta.hat <- mean(exp(-x)) - (mean(x) - 0.5)
theta.hat
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Antithetic Variables

Explanation of antithetic variables and how they reduce variance
Example: Applying antithetic variables

```{r}
# Antithetic variables example
u <- runif(5000)
theta.hat <- mean((exp(-u) + exp(-(1 - u))) / 2)
theta.hat
1 - exp(-1)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Random Variables and Distributions

Overview of random variables
Discrete vs Continuous random variables
Important distributions (Binomial, Normal, Chi-Square)

```{r}
# Simulating random variables
N <- 100; mu <- 5; sig <- 2
Y <- rnorm(N, mean = mu, sd = sig)
hist(Y, main="Histogram of Normal Distribution", xlab="Y values", col="lightblue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Example: Central Limit Theorem

Discuss the CLT and its importance in statistics
Simulating the CLT with normal distributions

```{r}
# Central Limit Theorem simulation
means <- replicate(1000, mean(rnorm(100, mean = mu, sd = sig)))
hist(means, main="Central Limit Theorem", col="lightgreen", border="black")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Common Distributions in Statistical Computing

Binomial Distribution
Poisson Distribution
Normal Distribution and its properties

```{r}
# Simulating binomial and Poisson distributions
x_binom <- rbinom(100, size = 10, prob = 0.5)
x_pois <- rpois(100, lambda = 3)

par(mfrow=c(1, 2))  # Two plots side by side
hist(x_binom, main="Binomial Distribution", col="orange")
hist(x_pois, main="Poisson Distribution", col="lightcoral")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Joint and Conditional Distributions

Joint distributions and their importance
Conditional distributions with examples

```{r}
# Simulating joint distributions
mu <- c(5, 10); sigma <- matrix(c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 2), 2, 2)
library(MASS)
X <- mvrnorm(1000, mu = mu, Sigma = sigma)

plot(X[,1], X[,2], main="Scatter plot of Joint Distribution", xlab="X1", ylab="X2", col="blue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Estimators and Their Properties

Discuss point estimators: Mean, Variance, etc.
Review bias, consistency, and efficiency

```{r}
# Example of calculating mean and variance from samples
set.seed(123)
sample_data <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2)
mean(sample_data)
var(sample_data)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Hypothesis Testing

Hypothesis testing steps
Type I and II errors, significance level, and power

```{r}
# Example of hypothesis testing
t_test_result <- t.test(rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2), mu=5)
t_test_result
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Confidence Intervals

Constructing confidence intervals for population mean
Example with real data

```{r}
# Example: Confidence interval for normal data
conf_interval <- t.test(rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2))$conf.int
conf_interval
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to Optimization

Overview of optimization methods
Example: One-dimensional optimization using optimize

```{r}
f <- function(x) log(x + log(x)) / log(1 + x)

# Plotting the function
curve(f(x), from = 2, to = 15, ylab = "f(x)")

# Finding the maximum
res <- optimize(f, lower = 4, upper = 8, maximum = TRUE)
abline(v=res$maximum)
res$maximum
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Optimization Results
```{r}
# Add a line indicating the maximum
abline(v=res$maximum, col = "red", lwd = 2)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to MLE

Introduction to Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)
Example: MLE for Gamma distribution

```{r}
# MLE for Gamma distribution
m <- 20000
est <- matrix(0, m, 2)
n <- 2000
r <- 5
lambda <- 2

obj <- function(lambda, xbar, logx.bar) {
  r <- length(xbar)
  log(lambda) - lambda * mean(xbar) + logx.bar
}
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Optimizing MLE
```{r}
# Optimizing the MLE
xbar <- rnorm(n, mean = r/lambda, sd = 1)
logx.bar <- mean(log(xbar))
result <- optimize(obj, lower = 1, upper = 10, xbar = xbar, logx.bar = logx.bar, maximum = TRUE)
result
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of one-dimensional optimization and MLE techniques
Practice: Apply optimization to other statistical problems and models





üîó tinyurl.com/Comp-Stat

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Sampling from a Finite Population

Introduction to finite population sampling
Example: Tossing coins, choosing lottery numbers

```{r}
# Sampling examples
sample(0:1, size = 10, replace = TRUE)  # Tossing coins
sample(1:100, size = 6, replace = FALSE)  # Choosing lottery numbers
sample(letters)  # Permutation of letters
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Multinomial Distribution

Introduction to multinomial distribution
Example: Sampling from a multinomial distribution

```{r}
# Sample from multinomial distribution
x <- sample(1:3, size = 100, replace = TRUE, prob = c(.2, .3, .5))
table(x)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Continuous Case

Explanation of the inverse transform method for continuous distributions
Example: Simulating exponential random variables

```{r}
# Inverse transform method for exponential distribution
n <- 1000
U <- runif(n)
X <- -log(1 - U)
hist(X, main="Exponential Distribution via Inverse Transform", col="lightblue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Discrete Case

Example of applying the inverse transform method to discrete random variables

```{r}
# Inverse transform method for geometric distribution
p <- 0.5
X_geom <- ceiling(log(1 - runif(n)) / log(1 - p))
hist(X_geom, main="Geometric Distribution via Inverse Transform", col="lightgreen")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Introduction to Acceptance-Rejection Method

Explanation of the acceptance-rejection method
Example: Sampling from a target distribution

```{r}
# Acceptance-rejection method example
target <- function(x) { ifelse(x > 0, exp(-x), 0) }
proposal <- function(x) { dnorm(x, mean = 2, sd = 1) }

X <- rnorm(1000, mean = 2, sd = 1)
accept <- runif(1000) < target(X) / (1.5 * proposal(X))

hist(X[accept], main="Accepted Samples from Target Distribution", col="lightcoral")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Visualizing Results

Compare the target and proposal distributions 31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602::31b8e172-b470-440e-83d8-e6b185028602

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Transformation of Random Variables

Introduction to transformation methods
Example: Box-Muller transform for generating normal random variables

```{r}
# Box-Muller transform
n <- 1000
U1 <- runif(n)
U2 <- runif(n)
Z1 <- sqrt(-2 * log(U1)) * cos(2 * pi * U2)
Z2 <- sqrt(-2 * log(U1)) * sin(2 * pi * U2)
hist(Z1, main="Normal Distribution via Box-Muller", col="lightblue")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Sums and Mixtures

Explanation of sums and mixtures of random variables
Example: Mixture of normals

```{r}
# Mixture of normals
library(MASS)
mu1 <- 0; mu2 <- 3; sigma1 <- 1; sigma2 <- 2
p <- 0.3
X <- ifelse(runif(n) < p, rnorm(n, mu1, sigma1), rnorm(n, mu2, sigma2))
hist(X, main="Mixture of Normal Distributions", col="lightgreen")
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Numerical Precision and Floating-Point Arithmetic

Introduction to floating-point arithmetic in R
Brain teasers: TRUE or FALSE?

```{r}
# Examples of floating-point precision
1==1
3-2==1
0.3-0.2==0.1
0.4-0.2==0.2
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Binary Representation

Discussion on binary fractions and limitations
Resources:

Binary Fraction Calculator
Floating Point Problem

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Iterative Methods

Introduction to iterative methods in numerical analysis

```{r}
# Example: Calculating large integers
as.integer(2^31-1)
as.integer(2^31)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Numerical Integration

Example of numerical integration using base R functions

```{r}
# Numerical integration using integrate function
f <- function(x) sin(x)
integrate(f, lower = 0, upper = pi)
```

title: Computational Statistics
text:
Conclusion

Recap of numerical precision, floating-point arithmetic, and numerical integration methods
Practice: Apply numerical methods to solve optimization and integration problems

Instructor Details

Name: Mehdi Maadooliat, Ph.D.
Office: CU 351
Office Hours: TuTh 12:25 - 1:55pm in CU 351 or by e-mail

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Course Description
Computational statistics and statistical computing are two areas that employ computational, graphical, and numerical approaches to solve statistical problems. Competent statisticians must not just run existing programs but understand the principles behind them. This class introduces statistically-oriented programming targeted at statistics majors, with no extensive programming background assumed.
This course covers traditional core material of computational statistics with an emphasis on using R through an example-based approach.

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of the course, students will: - Understand core programming concepts, including data structures, functions, iteration, debugging, logical design, and abstraction. - Write maintainable code, debug, and test code for correctness. - Set up and run stochastic simulations in parallel. - Fit basic statistical models and assess the results. - Work with and filter large datasets. - Comment and organize code effectively.

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Prerequisites

COSC 1010
MATH 3100
MATH 4700 or MATH 4780

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Textbooks

Main: Statistical Computing with R, 2nd edition by Maria L. Rizzo. Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2019. ISBN: 1466553324.
Supplementary: Computational Statistics, 2nd Edition by Geof H. Givens and Jennifer A. Hoeting. Wiley, 2012. ISBN: 9780470533314.

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Attendance
Attendance is required and subject to the College of Arts and Sciences policy.

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Academic Honesty
Students are expected to follow the University‚Äôs policy on academic honesty as outlined in the Bulletin.
TL;DR: Don‚Äôt cheat!
Please abide by the following as you work on assignments in this course:

Collaboration: Only work that is clearly assigned as team work should be completed collaboratively.

The homework assignments must also be completed individually and you are welcomed to discuss the assignment with classmates at a high level (e.g., discuss what‚Äôs the best way for approaching a problem, what functions are useful for accomplishing a particular task, etc.). However you may not directly share answers to lab questions (including any code) with anyone other than myself and the teaching assistants.
The reading quizzes must be completed individually with absolutely no communication with classmates.
For the projects, collaboration within teams is not only allowed, but expected. Communication between teams at a high level is also allowed however you may not share code or components of the project across teams.
On individual assignments you may not directly share code with another student in this class, and on team assignments you may not directly share code with another team in this class.

Online resources: I am well aware that a huge volume of code is available on the web to solve any number of problems. Unless I explicitly tell you not to use something, the course‚Äôs policy is that you may make use of any online resources (e.g., StackOverflow) but you must explicitly cite where you obtained any code you directly use (or use as inspiration). Any recycled code that is discovered and is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism.
Use of generative artificial intelligence (AI): You should treat generative AI, such as ChatGPT, the same as other online resources. There are two guiding principles that govern how you can use AI in this course:1 (1) Cognitive dimension: Working with AI should not reduce your ability to think clearly. We will practice using AI to facilitate‚Äîrather than hinder‚Äîlearning. (2) Ethical dimension: Students using AI should be transparent about their use and make sure it aligns with academic integrity.

‚úÖ AI tools for code: You may make use of the technology for coding examples on assignments; if you do so, you must explicitly cite where you obtained the code. Any recycled code that is discovered and is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism. You may use these guidelines for citing AI-generated content.
‚ùå AI tools for narrative: Unless instructed otherwise, you may not use generative AI to write narrative on assignments. In general, you may use generative AI as a resource as you complete assignments but not to answer the exercises for you.

You are ultimately responsible for the work you turn in; it should reflect your understanding of the course content.

If you are unsure if the use of a particular resource complies with the academic honesty policy, please ask the instructor.

title: Syllabus - MATH 4750/MSSC 5750: Computational Statistics
text:
Course Topics

Managing Input/Output in R
Data structures in R
Data transformations: strings, factors, dates
Statistical summaries and basic tests in R
Graphics in R
Monte Carlo Integration & Variance Reduction
Bootstrap and Jackknife
Density Estimation
Regularization:

Ridge and Lasso
Smoothing

Dimension Reduction and Clustering

K-Means and Hierarchical Clustering
Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

Numerical Methods in R

Optimization
Expectation-Maximization (EM) Algorithm

Advanced R Programming

Introduction to Parallel Computing
Object Oriented Programming in R
Developing an R Package
Developing an Interactive Shiny App
Functions and loops in C and using C in R

Deep Learning in R

Basics of Neural Network

Implementation using TensorFlow and Keras

Fully Connected Network (FCN)
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)

title: HW 1 (MATH 4750/5750)
text:
Extra Question
Follow the example we had in the classroom, find the \(E(X)\) and \(Var(X)\) based on (i) equations (2.1) and (2.2), and (ii) simulation for the following cases. Does (i) and (ii) give you the same result?
(a) \(X\sim\chi^2(\nu=N+1)\), where \(N\sim Poisson(\lambda)\).
(b) (Only for Graduate Students) \(X\sim Binomial(n=Y, p=P)\), where \(Y\sim Poisson(\lambda)\) and \(P\sim Beta(\alpha, \beta)\).
